{{Infobox film | name = The Meg | image = The Meg.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Jon Turteltaub]] | producers = {{Plainlist| * [[Lorenzo di Bonaventura]] * [[Colin Wilson (film producer)|Colin Wilson]] * Belle Avery }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Dean Georgaris * Jon Hoeber * Erich Hoeber }} | based on = {{based on|''[[Meg: A Novel of Deep Terror]]''|[[Steve Alten]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Jason Statham]] * [[Li Bingbing]] * [[Rainn Wilson]] * [[Ruby Rose]] * [[Winston Chao]] * [[Cliff Curtis]] }} | music = [[Harry Gregson-Williams]] | cinematography = [[Tom Stern (cinematographer)|Tom Stern]] | editing = Steven Kemper | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] * Gravity Pictures * [[Flagship Entertainment]] * Apelles Entertainment * [[Di Bonaventura Pictures]] * Maeday Productions }} | distributor = [[Warner Bros. Pictures]] | released = {{film date|2018|8|10|United States}} | runtime = 113 minutes<ref>{{cite web |title=THE MEG (12A) |url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/meg-film |website=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=July 5, 2018 |accessdate=July 5, 2018}}</ref> | country = {{ubl|China|United States}} | language = English | budget = <!--RANGE PER SOURCE, DO NOT CHANGE FROM 130–178-->$130–178 million<!--RANGE PER SOURCE, DO NOT CHANGE FROM $130--><ref name="THR"/><ref name=opening/> | gross = $527.8 million<ref name=BOM>{{cite web |title=The Meg (2018) |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=wbeventfilm2018.htm |website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=October 29, 2018}}</ref> }} '''''The Meg''''' is a 2018 [[science fiction film|science fiction]] [[action film|action]] <!--PER SOURCES-->[[thriller film|thriller]]<!--PER SOURCES--> film directed by [[Jon Turteltaub]] with a screenplay by Dean Georgaris, Jon Hoeber, and Erich Hoeber, loosely based on the 1997 book ''[[Meg: A Novel of Deep Terror]]'' by [[Steve Alten]]. The film stars [[Jason Statham]], [[Li Bingbing]], [[Rainn Wilson]], [[Ruby Rose]], [[Winston Chao]], and [[Cliff Curtis]]. The film follows a group of scientists who encounter a {{convert|75|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} [[megalodon]] shark while on a rescue mission at the [[Deep sea|floor of the Pacific Ocean]].
[[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] originally purchased the film rights to the book in the 1990s, but after several years in [[development hell]], the rights landed at [[Warner Bros.]] The film was eventually [[green-light|greenlit]] in 2015. Turteltaub and much of the cast joined by September 2016, and filming began the following month in New Zealand and ended in [[Sanya]], China in January 2017.
A Chinese-American co-production, ''The Meg'' was released in both countries on August 10, 2018, in [[RealD 3D]]. It has grossed over $527 million worldwide and received mixed reviews from critics, with some describing it as an entertaining B-movie and others calling it "neither good enough nor bad enough" to be fun.
==Plot== <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for feature films should be between 400 to 700 words. --> A rescue team led by Jonas Taylor is saving a group of sailors trapped inside a sunken [[nuclear submarine]] when Jonas sees the hull of the submarine being damaged by an unknown creature. Two rescuers are stuck in the damaged submarine and say their return to the rescue submersible will take a few minutes. Taylor leaves them behind as he is afraid they will all die if they wait. As they leave, the damaged sub explodes. Taylor's claim is that a giant sea creature caused the disaster. He is dismissed by his teammate Dr. Heller, who believes Taylor was affected with pressure-induced psychosis and blames Jonas for the loss of their friends.
Five years later, billionaire Jack Morris meets Dr. Minway Zhang at the underwater research facility "Mana One", which Morris finances. Zhang and his daughter, Suyin, an oceanographer, are supervising a mission to explore what may be a deeper section of the [[Marianas trench]], concealed by a [[thermocline]] cloud of [[hydrogen sulfide]]. The mission is being conducted by Lori (Taylor's ex-wife), Toshi, and The Wall in a submersible. The mission appears to be going well until a very large creature hits the submersible, causing it to lose contact with Mana One.
James "Mac" Mackreides, another crew member at the station, suggests sending Taylor down to attempt a rescue, citing the similarity to his story. Despite Heller's objections, Zhang and Mac decide to travel to Thailand to recruit Taylor anyway. Suyin attempts the rescue herself after receiving a signal from submerisble, but a [[colossal squid]] intervenes. Before it can destroy her craft, a massive shark appears and kills it. Agreeing to help, Taylor reaches the trapped submersible, saving Lori and The Wall. However, when the giant shark returns, Toshi sacrifices himself by closing the hatch door and detaching the rescue vessel. But before he did that, Toshi makes sure that the letter to his wife will be given by putting it inside The Wall's pocket. This allows Taylor, Lori, and The Wall to escape safely while he diverts the shark's attention to his sub, causing it to be driven into a [[thermal vent]], causing an explosion.
Back at Mana One, the crew discovers that the shark is a [[Megalodon]], the largest shark ever known, believed to be extinct for millions of years. Meanwhile, Suyin's daughter, Meiying, goes to the large glass leading to a beautiful underwater view of the ocean, and sees the Megalodon through the glass, and is petrified. When Suyin comes down with Jonas, they see a whale being eaten alive by the massive shark. The crew then realize that it has escaped from the depths of the trench by swimming through a hole in the thermocline created by the thermal vent explosion, briefly raising the temperature enough for it to safely pass. The group decides to track and poison the Megalodon, which they succeed in doing. While injecting the Megalodon with [[etorphine]], Suyin's oxygen mask gets compromised, but Taylor revives her with [[CPR]]. Despite initial success, Taylor comments that the teeth don't match up with the previous attack. Shortly after, a second, more colossal Megalodon emerges from the water, devours The Wall and the smaller Megalodon, and capsizes the boat. It also devours Dr. Heller, who saves Jaxx's life by luring it to himself. The surviving crew returns to Mana One in two dinghies, but Dr. Zhang succumbs and dies of his injuries. Morris announces that he has informed local governments and naval forces, but it is out of their hands. He dismissed the whole crew and advised them to evacuate in the morning.
At nightfall, Morris attempts to destroy the Megalodon himself by ordering a helicopter crew to drop modified [[depth charge]]s at it, citing that the creature's actions could result in lawsuits. He approaches the carcass of the supposed Megalodon in a boat but discovers it's a whale. When the Megalodon approaches, the boat accelerates, causing Morris to fall overboard and be eaten by the Megalodon. Taylor and the remaining Mana One crew discover Morris' deception and resolve to track and kill the shark, only to realize that it is en route to a crowded beach on the [[Sanya Bay]].
The Megalodon kills several beachgoers before the Mana One crew plays audio of a whale call to divert the shark's attention towards them. Taylor and Suyin attempt to destroy the megalodon with rigged torpedoes, to no avail, and in the process, Taylor's submersible is severely damaged. Taylor manages to cut the megalodon with parts of his sub and stab it in the eye with a harpoon. Due to the presence of blood, multiple sharks in the area notice the blood and devour the Megalodon, killing it. During the fight, Suyin was able to evacuate everyone to a boat where a Chinese couple is getting married. Taylor gets on the boat, and he and Suyin consider taking a vacation to celebrate their triumph.
==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=35em}} * [[Jason Statham]] as Jonas Taylor * [[Li Bingbing]] as Suyin Zhang * [[Rainn Wilson]] as Jack Morris * [[Winston Chao]] as Dr. Minway Zhang * Sophia Cai as Meiying * [[Cliff Curtis]] as James "Mac" Mackreides * [[Ruby Rose]] as Jaxx Herd * [[Page Kennedy]] as DJ * [[Jessica McNamee]] as Lori * [[Robert Taylor (Australian actor)|Robert Taylor]] as Dr. Heller * [[Ólafur Darri Ólafsson]] as The Wall * [[Masi Oka]] as Toshi
{{div col end}}
==Production== ===Development=== The rights to the novel were initially acquired by [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Disney]]'s [[Hollywood Pictures]] in 1996.<ref name=Wired>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/story/the-meg-movie/ |website=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |title=The 20-Year Journey of 'The Meg'—the Movie the Internet Wouldn't Let Die |first=Brian |last=Raftery |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=August 9, 2018}}</ref> Around that time, [[Tom Wheeler (writer)|Tom Wheeler]] was hired to adapt the book into a screenplay, but, having decided that his script wasn't good enough, the studio hired [[Jeffrey Boam]] to write a new draft. Boam's script was later rejected for the same reason.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/horror/news/707242-the-details-of-megs-demise |title=The Details of Meg's Demise |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |website=ComingSoon.net |publisher=[[CraveOnline|Mandatory]] |first=Ryan |last=Turek |date=July 12, 2007}}</ref> By 1999 the project had stalled and the rights reverted to [[Steve Alten]], the book's author.<ref name=Wired />
In 2005, reports surfaced that the project was being developed by [[New Line Cinema]], with an estimated budget of $75 million, and a slated release of summer 2006.<ref name=LATimes>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/apr/13/entertainment/ca-newline13 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |title=Trapped down in the depths |date=April 13, 2008 |first=Robert W. |last=Welkos |accessdate=August 20, 2018}}</ref> Names attached to the production included [[Jan de Bont]] as director, [[Guillermo Del Toro]] as producer and [[Shane Salerno]] as screenwriter. However, New Line later cancelled the project due to budgetary concerns.<ref name=LATimes /> The rights reverted to Alten again, but the film remained in [[development hell]].
In 2015, it was announced that the film was now moving forward at [[Warner Bros.]], with a new script written by Dean Georgaris.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tracking-board.com/tb-exclusive-long-awaited-giant-shark-thriller-meg-swims-to-warner-bros/ |website=The Tracking Board |title=Long-Awaited Giant Shark Thriller 'Meg' Swims To Warner Bros. |date=June 3, 2015 |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |first=Clark |last=Allen}}</ref> By June of that year, [[Eli Roth]] was reported to be in talks to direct,<ref name=VarietyJune>{{cite magazine |first=Justin |last=Kroll |title=Eli Roth to Direct Giant Shark Thriller 'Meg' for Warner Bros |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/eli-roth-direct-giant-shark-thriller-meg-for-warner-bros-1201520955/ |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=June 16, 2015}}</ref> but, due to creative differences, Roth was replaced by [[Jon Turteltaub]] in early 2016.<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Chitwood |title=Eli Roth Exits Giant Shark Movie 'Meg' |url=http://collider.com/eli-roth-shark-movie-meg-jon-turteltaub/ |accessdate=August 10, 2018 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex Media]] |date=March 6, 2016}}</ref> [[Jason Statham]] and much of the cast joined in August and September 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jason Statham Is Going to Fight a Giant Dinosaur Shark in 'Meg' |url=http://collider.com/jason-statham-meg-shark/ |first=Haleigh |last=Foutch |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex Media]] |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |date=April 14, 2016}}</ref> ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] on the film began on October 13, 2016, in West Auckland, New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web |first=Karen |last=Butler |title=Jason Statham, Jon Turteltaub start shooting shark tale 'Meg' in New Zealand |url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/Movies/2016/10/15/Jason-Statham-Jon-Turteltaub-start-shooting-shark-tale-Meg-in-New-Zealand/1101476584740/ |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |website=[[United Press International]] |date=October 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Meg: Filming Begins on Giant Shark Movie with Jason Statham |url=http://collider.com/meg-filming-begins-jason-statham-li-bingbing/ |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex Media]] |date=October 13, 2016 |first=Adam |last=Chitwood}}</ref> Filming ended on January 4, 2017, in [[Sanya City]] of [[Hainan]], China.<ref>{{cite web |title=李冰冰杰森斯坦森联袂《巨齿鲨》杀青后期制作一年2018年上映 |language=zh |url=http://news.mtime.com/2017/01/04/1565105.html |website=[[Mtime.com]] |accessdate=August 13, 2018 |date=January 13, 2018}}</ref> ===Visual effects=== Visual effects were done by ''[[Sony Imageworks]]'', ''[[Image Engine]]'' and ''[[Scanline VFX]]''. The visual effects team was challenged with not only designing a previously undiscovered prehistoric giant shark, but also designing the underwater environments and atmospherics, including realistic coral reefs, bubbles, and other sea life.<ref>{{cite web |title=THE MEG: How Imageworks Helped Make a Massive Megalodon |url=http://vfxvoice.com/the-meg-how-imageworks-helped-make-a-massive-megalodon/ |first=Ian |last=Failes |website=VFX Voice |accessdate=September 11, 2018 |date=September 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Entrenched in the Deep, Dark Depths with THE MEG|url=http://vfxvoice.com/entrenched-in-the-deep-dark-depths-with-the-meg/ |first=Trevor |last=Hogg |website=VFX Voice |accessdate=September 21, 2018 |date=September 17, 2018}}</ref>
==Release== Released by Gravity Pictures in China and by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] in the United States, ''The Meg'' was originally scheduled to open March 2, 2018.<ref name=May2016V>{{cite magazine |first=Dave |last=McNary |title=Jason Statham's Shark Movie 'Meg' Gets 2018 Release Date |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/meg-release-date-jason-statham-1201776331/ |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=May 16, 2016}}</ref> Warner and Gravity then said that the film would be released during the 2018 Chinese New Year period in China, a week-long annual holiday that kicked off on February 16, 2018. The film was later pushed back to its eventual date of August 10, 2018, in 3D and IMAX.<ref name="move">{{cite magazine |last=McNary |first=Dave |title=Jason Statham's Shark Thriller 'Meg' Swims Back Five Months |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/jason-statham-shark-thriller-meg-2018-1202001256/ |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=March 2, 2017 |accessdate=September 17, 2017}}</ref>
The first official trailer was released on April 9, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bsLk0NPRFAc |title=THE MEG - Official Trailer #1 [HD] |website=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=June 26, 2018 |author=[[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] |date=April 9, 2018}}</ref> The studio spent $140 million on global prints and advertisement for the film.<ref name=opening/>
===Home media=== ''The Meg'' was released for [[digital distribution|digital download]] on October 30, 2018, and on [[Ultra HD Blu-ray]], [[Blu-ray]] and [[DVD]] on November 13.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bloody-disgusting.com/home-video/3524876/chomping-500-million-worldwide-meg-swims-home-video-november |title=After Chomping Up Over $500 Million Worldwide, ‘The Meg’ Swims to Home Video in November |accessdate=October 3, 2018}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''The Meg'' has grossed $143 million in the United States and Canada, and $384.8 million in other territories, for a total worldwide gross of $527.8 million, against a production budget between $130–178 million.<ref name=BOM/>
In the United States and Canada, ''The Meg'' was released alongside ''[[Slender Man (film)|Slender Man]]'' and ''[[BlacKkKlansman]]'', and was originally projected to gross $20–22 million from 4,118 theaters in its opening weekend.<ref name=THR>{{cite magazine |last=McClintock |first=Pamela |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-preview-big-budget-meg-heads-tepid-20m-us-debut-1133093 |title=Box-Office Preview: Big-Budget 'The Meg' Heads for Tepid $20M-Plus U.S. Debut |magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=August 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 8, 2018}}</ref> The film made $4 million from Thursday night previews, leading analysts to predict it would outperform its low-$20 million projections. After making $16.5 million on its first day, weekend estimates were raised to $40 million.<ref name=opening>{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/the-meg-chomps-a-huge-4m-on-thursday-night-box-office-1202443644/ |title='Meg's Opening Grows To $40M+…But Is It Big Enough? What The Shark Movie Means During Trump's Trade War With China |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 11, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=August 11, 2018}}</ref> It went on to debut to $45.4 million, topping the box office and marking the best solo opening of Statham's career, as well as Turteltaub.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/august-audiences-get-hooked-on-meg-shelling-out-44m-45m-early-sunday-am-box-office-1202444210/ |title='August Audiences Get Hooked On 'Meg' Shelling Out $44.5M |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 12, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=August 12, 2018}}</ref> It made $21.5 million in its second weekend and $13 million in its third, finishing second behind ''[[Crazy Rich Asians (film)|Crazy Rich Asians]]'' both times.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/crazy-rich-asians-wednesday-opening-box-office-1202446094/ |title='Crazy Rich Asians' Even Richer On Saturday With $10M+; Weekend Bling Now At $25M+ With $34M 5-Day Debut |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 19, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=August 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/melissa-mccarthy-happytime-murders-crazy-rich-asians-meg-weekend-box-office-1202451694/ |title='Why 'Happytime Murders' Reps A Solo Career B.O. Low For Melissa McCarthy In A 'Crazy Rich' Weekend – Update |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 26, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref>
In other territories, the film debuted to $101.5 million from 96 countries, for a worldwide opening of $146.9 million. In China, a co-producer of the film, it grossed $50.3 million from 12,650 screens, ranked 3 in the opening weekend. Other top openings were Mexico ($6.2 million), Russia ($5 million), the United Kingdom ($4.4 million), Spain ($2.4 million) and the Philippines ($2 million).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/the-meg-opening-weekend-mission-impossible-fallout-incredibles-2-china-global-international-box-office-1202444233/ |title='The Meg' Devours $97M Overseas/$141M Global Opening; 'Fallout' Flies Past $400M WW – International Box Office |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 12, 2018 |first=Nancy |last=Tartaglione |accessdate=August 12, 2018}}</ref>
===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 45% based on 240 reviews, and an average rating of 5.4/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''The Meg'' sets audiences up for a good old-fashioned B-movie creature feature, but lacks the genre thrills -- or the cheesy bite -- to make it worth diving in."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Meg (2018)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_meg|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 46 out of 100 based on 46 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-meg|title=The Meg Reviews|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B+" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="opening"/>
[[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a mixed review, calling it "neither good enough -- nor bad enough," and writing, "''The Meg'', a rote sci-fi horror adventure film that features a shark the size of a blue whale, comes on like it wants to be the mother of all deep-sea attack movies. But it's really just the mother of all generically pandering, totally unsurprising ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' ripoffs."<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Gleiberman |first=Owen |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/the-meg-review-jason-statham-1202896831/ |title=Film Review: 'The Meg' |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 9, 2018 }}</ref> In a more positive review, Alex Hudson from ''[[Exclaim!]]'' said the film succeeded nicely on modest terms; "As pulpy action films go, this is the best blockbuster about prehistoric monsters you'll see this summer. Sorry, ''[[Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom|Jurassic World]]''."<ref>{{cite web |last=Hudson |first=Alex |title='The Meg' Review: Outrageous Shark Romp Brings Prehistoric Thrills |url=https://exclaim.ca/film/article/the_meg_review_outrageous_shark_romp_brings_prehistoric_thrills-directed_by_jon_turteltaub |website=[[Exclaim!]] |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |date=August 9, 2018}}</ref> Scott Mendelson of ''[[Forbes]]'' was impressed by the film's special effects and called it "a polished B movie that delivers the goods,"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mendelson |first1=Scott |title=Review: Jason Statham's 'The Meg' Is So Much Better Than 'Sharknado' |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2018/08/09/review-jason-stathams-the-meg-is-so-much-better-than-sharknado/ |website=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |date=August 9, 2018}}</ref> while [[IGN]]'s William Bibbiani praised the performances of the cast, particularly Statham.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bibbiani |first1=William |title=The Meg Review |url=http://m.uk.ign.com/articles/2018/08/09/the-meg-review |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=August 9, 2018 |accessdate=August 10, 2018}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', Simon Abrams said the film was "refreshingly unpretentious" and "a breath of fresh air" compared to the ''[[Sharknado (film series)|Sharknado]]'' series.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Abrams |first1=Simon |title='The Meg' Feels Refreshingly Unpretentious|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/how-meg-rose-sharknado-stigma-1134170 |magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=August 13, 2018 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref>
== Sequel == In April 2018, Jason Statham said a ''Meg'' sequel would happen if the film did well with the public, saying "I think it's like anything in this day and age — if it makes money, there's obviously an appetite to make more money. And if it doesn't do well, they'll soon sweep it under the carpet. But that's the way Hollywood works."<ref>https://ew.com/movies/2018/04/23/jason-statham-the-meg-sequel/</ref> That August, Steve Alten said "My feeling has always been that this is a billion dollar franchise if it was done right. But to be done right you had to get the shark right, get the cast right, get the tone right. And Warner Bros. have nailed it completely. The producers have nailed it."<ref>https://www.metro.us/entertainment/movies/will-there-be-a-sequel-to-the-meg-writer-steve-alten-talks-us-through-it</ref>
In October 2018, executive producer Catherine Xujun Ying announced a sequel was in the early stages of development.<ref>https://deadline.com/2018/10/the-meg-2-early-development-warner-bros-china-1202492498/</ref> Alten said in his September 2018 newsletter that he will be asking for more creative control on the sequel.

revision.text:
{{About||the movie starring [[Martin Sheen]]|The Vessel (2016 film)}} '''The Vessel''' is a British comedy web series created and written by Chloe Seddon, Phillip Whiteman and Giovanni Bienne. The series is broadcast on the Internet and premiered on October 21, 2012. Currently 10 episodes have been made and the show can be found distributed across the web on platforms including [[Blip (website)|Blip]] and [[YouTube]]. The Vessel Series follows Kim (Lily Brown) and her two best friends, Rory (Giovanni Bienne) and Mike (Phillip Whiteman), as they start a family. Rory and Mike are a gay couple who have decided they want to have a baby. Rory and Mike want a baby, so they ask their close friend Kim to be the surrogate mother.{{cite web|last=Anon|title=Exclusive: 'Watch The Vessel'|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2012/10/07/exclusive-watch-vessel|work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|accessdate=5 April 2013}} == The Vessel (Web Series) == {{Infobox television |show_name = The Vessel Series |image = |genre = [[Comedy]] |creator = Chloe Seddon, Phillip Whiteman |starring = [[Giovanni Bienne]]
Phillip Whiteman
Lily Brown |composer = James Jones |country = United Kingdom |language = English |num_seasons = 1 |num_episodes = 10 |list_episodes = |producer = Chloe Seddon
Phillip Whiteman |distributor = Independent (2012, 2013–) |location = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |runtime = 5 - 10 minutes |network = [[YouTube]]
[[Blip (website)|Blip]] |first_aired = {{Start date|2012|10|21}} |last_aired = {{end date|2012|12|23}} |website = http://www.thevesselseries.com/ }} == History == In an interview with the creators, Chloe Seddon and Phillip Whiteman stated that the idea came from when they were asked to improvise an audition. 'We chose the scenario of a gay couple asking their best friend to be the surrogate.'{{cite web|last=Tangled Web Watch|title=Interview with Chloe Seddon and Phillip Whiteman, Writers of the Brilliant UK Web Series: The Vessel|url=http://tangledwebwewatch.com/2012/12/03/uk-web-series-corner-interview-with-chloe-seddon-and-phillip-whiteman-writers-of-the-brilliant-uk-web-series-the-vessel/|work=tangledwebwewatch.com|accessdate=4 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213210556/http://tangledwebwewatch.com/2012/12/03/uk-web-series-corner-interview-with-chloe-seddon-and-phillip-whiteman-writers-of-the-brilliant-uk-web-series-the-vessel/|archivedate=13 February 2015|df=}} In 2011, The Vessel Series was awarded 'best webseries pilot' at the London [[Raindance Film Festival]].{{cite web|last=Timeout|title=Watch the exclusive premiere of new comedy show ‘The Vessel’|url=http://now-here-this.timeout.com/2012/10/21/the-vessel/|work=now-here-this.timeout.com/|accessdate=4 April}} The Vessel Series has won awards including ‘Best Produced Comedy Web Series’ at [[Web series#Events and festivals|LA Web Fest 2013]]. The series also picked up ‘Best Supporting Actor’ awards for Robin Soans and Louise Jameson.{{cite web|last=LA Web Festival |title=2013 LA Web Fest Award Winners |url=http://www.lawebfest.com/2013-LAWEBFEST-AWARD-WINNERS.html |work=lawebfest.com/ |accessdate=5 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702035502/http://www.lawebfest.com/2013-LAWEBFEST-AWARD-WINNERS.html |archivedate=July 2, 2013 }} == Plot == The Vessel Series deals with the controversial topics of [[LGBT parenting]] and [[surrogacy]]. It is filmed from the perspective of the surrogate mother (Kim), so the audience get to see the action through the surrogates eyes and never see Kim’s face or reactions, which is in a similar format to the series ‘[[Peep Show (TV series)|Peep Show]].’ Every Episode is shot as a single continuous take as well as the script being improvised.{{cite web|last=Lees|first=Paris|title=The Vessel Series|url=http://www.gaytimes.co.uk/Interact/Blogs-articleid-9308-sectionid-780.html|work=gaytimes.co.uk|accessdate=April 4, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113151230/http://www.gaytimes.co.uk/Interact/Blogs-articleid-9308-sectionid-780.html|archivedate=November 13, 2012|df=}} === Season 1 === Episode 1: A Mega Favour - Rory and Mike have a favour to ask Kim. Will she be their tummy mummy?
Episode 2: Not actual Turkeys - The trio visit a surrogacy consultant to find out the best way to get Kim pregnant.
Episode 3: A bit pregnant - Rory It's the big moment as Kim takes a pregnancy test, but is she truly ready for the result?
Episode 4: God didn't give either of them a womb - Kim's Mum The threesome invite Kim's parents over for dinner to break the news.
Episode 5: The Teacher's a Psychopath - Kim The boys' rigid pregnancy regime and Kim's fiery pregnancy hormones make a volatile combination when choosing baby names.
Episode 6: The Third dad - Kim It's Kim's third date with the hot guy Luke since she became pregnant and she has a special proposition for him.
Episode 7: Damn that's my ex...Tim - Rory While out for a walk in the park with Kim, Rory bumps into his ex-boyfriend.
Episode 8: Stretch Marks - A night full of uncomfortable dreams fuels a heart to heart between Mike and Kim as they share their anxieties about the baby.
Episode 9: Natural History Museum - A trip to the Natural History Museum causes an argument between the boys and a shock for them all.
Episode 10: It might feel like you're having a bit of a poo - Midwife The baby arrives bringing a new way of life for the boys and a life changing decision for Kim. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|tt2298902}} * [http://www.thevesselseries.com Official Website] * [http://blip.tv/thevesselseries The Vessel Series] on Blip {{DEFAULTSORT:Vessel}} [[Category:British web series]] [[Category:2012 web series debuts]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}}
{{Infobox musical | name = Torsten the Bareback Saint | subtitle = | image = | image_size = | caption = | music = Christopher Frost | lyrics = Barney Ashton-Bullock | book = | basis = | setting = England | premiere_date = {{start date|2014|08|05|df=yes}} | premiere_location = Assembly Rooms Edinburgh | productions = 2014 [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] | awards = <!-- Please do not include production-specific (acting, directing, etc.) awards --> }}
'''''Torsten the Bareback Saint''''' is a [[one-person show]] and [[concept album]] written by playwright Barney Ashton-Bullock, and performed by pop singer [[Andy Bell (singer)|Andy Bell]] of the band [[Erasure]]. The score is composed, orchestrated and arranged by Christopher Frost and produced by Mike Allison.<ref name="Tyler">{{cite web |url=http://www.theartsdesk.com/new-music/cd-andy-bell-%E2%80%93-torsten-bareback-saint |title=CD: Andy Bell – ''Torsten the Bareback Saint'' |date=27 July 2014 |last=Tyler |first=Kieron |website=[[The Arts Desk]] |access-date=2016-03-21}}</ref>{{citation needed|reason=The Arts Desk article disagrees with this assertion|date=April 2016}} The [[artistic director]] was [[Predrag Pajdic]].<ref name="Tyler"/>
Promotional material for the show describes it as 'a set of musical postcards from the hotspots of memory of a semi-immortal [[polysexual]]'.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://themouthmagazine.com/2015/09/22/andy-bell-erasure/ |title=Andy Bell (Erasure) |date=22 September 2015 |author=Staff writer |authorlink=Staff writer |website=The Mouth Magazine |access-date=2016-03-21}}</ref> The music is an episodic [[song-cycle]], which Bell performs accompanied by a small [[musical ensemble]].<ref name="Guardian review">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jul/24/andy-bell-torsten-bareback-saint-review |title=Andy Bell: ''Torsten the Bareback Saint'' review – brave, bawdy concept album |date=24 July 2014 |last=Dennis |first=Jon |website=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=2016-03-21}}</ref>
Bell debuted the show at the 2014 [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]], where he performed at Assembly Studio One daily from the 5th through the 16th of August. Prior to the festival, he gave two private performances at the [[St. James Theatre]] in London. The first of these, on 24 July 2014, was for an invited audience of family and friends; the second, on 26 July, he performed for a small gathering of fans.
==Soundtrack album== {{Infobox album | name = Torsten the Bareback Saint | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Andy Bell (singer)|Andy Bell]] | cover = Torsten the Bareback Saint album cover.png | alt = | released = {{Start date|2014|07|28|df=yes}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | label = Strike Force Entertainment | producer = | prev_title = [[Non-Stop (Andy Bell album)|Non-Stop]] | prev_year = 2010 | next_title = | next_year = }}
A studio-recorded [[soundtrack album]] was released on 28 July 2014 by Strike Force Entertainment, an [[Sublabel|imprint]] of [[Cherry Red Records]].
{{Track listing | collapsed = no | headline = | extra_column = | total_length = 62:46

On the back cover of the retail CD release, the titles of tracks 1, 8, and 10 are censored: 'Freshly', 'V for…?', and 'Mobile'.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.saint-torsten.com/}} * {{Facebook|TorstenTheBarebackSaint|''Torsten the Bareback Saint''}} * {{YouTube|c=UCQcbwO_wl2wZZD24-gWmSrg|''Torsten the Bareback Saint''}} * {{Discogs master|714550|type=album}}
{{Andy Bell}}

page.title: Waseda University Tsubouchi Memorial Theatre Museum

revision.text:
{{coord|35.709973|139.719524|format=dms|display=title|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000}} [[File:Waseda Theatre Museum Tokyo Japan 2006-03-22.jpg|thumb|Tsubouchi Memorial Theatre Museum, also known as ''Enpaku'']] [[File:Tsubouchi Shyoyo 02.jpg|thumb|Bust of [[Tsubouchi Shōyō]] at the museum, which was named in his honour]] {{maplink|frame=yes|frame-width=220|zoom=16|type=shape}} The '''Tsubouchi Memorial Theatre Museum''' of [[Waseda University]] is a university museum devoted to the history of drama, with facilities used for cultural performances from all over the world. The museum was named for [[Tsubouchi Shōyō]], a famous writer known for his work with theater and translation of the collected works of [[Shakespeare]] into Japanese. It is commonly known as ''Enpaku'' in Japanese.<ref>演博, short for {{nihongo|演劇博物館|engeki hakubutsukan|extra="theatre museum"}}</ref>
==History== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Enpakuback.jpg|frame|]] --> The Waseda Theatre Museum formally opened in 1928, following the dreams of Professor Tsubouchi to build a museum dedicated to theatre arts. It commemorates all of Tsubouchi's accomplishments, among them a 40-volume translation of the works of Shakespeare that Tsubouchi also finished in 1928, the year of his 70th birthday. Modelled after the [[Fortune Playhouse|Fortune Theatre]] of [[London]], the museum approximates its inspiration in both exterior construction and interior design.
==Collections== The Waseda Theatre Museum functions as both a repository and exhibition space, housing nearly 37,000 items and 100,000 volumes. For example it has a large number of ''[[ukiyo-e]]'' prints depicting the popular [[kabuki]] play ''[[Chūshingura]]''.<ref>http://www.columbia.edu/~hds2/chushingura/exhibition/pt1.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Tsubouchi Memorial Theatre Museum}} *[http://www.waseda.jp/enpaku/index-e.html Waseda University | Enpaku]
{{Waseda University}} {{Portal bar|Asia|Japan|University|Theatre|Architecture}}
[[Category:Museums in Tokyo]] [[Category:Theatre museums]] [[Category:University museums in Japan]] [[Category:Waseda University]]

{{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Barbers' Baptism 147274.jpg|thumb|The Barbers' Play: The Baptism performed from a wagon in the street in York in 2014]] The '''York Mystery Plays''', more properly the '''York Corpus Christi Plays''', are a [[Middle English]] [[play cycle|cycle]] of 48 [[mystery play]]s or pageants covering sacred history from the [[Genesis creation myth|creation]] to the [[Last Judgment]]. They were traditionally presented on the feast day of [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]] (a movable feast on the Thursday after Trinity Sunday, between 23 May and 24 June) and were performed in the city of [[York]], from the mid-fourteenth century until their suppression in 1569. The plays are one of four virtually complete surviving English mystery play cycles, along with the [[Chester Mystery Plays]], the [[Wakefield Cycle|Towneley/Wakefield plays]] and the [[N-Town|N-Town plays]]. Two long, composite, and late mystery pageants have survived from the [[Coventry Mystery Plays|Coventry cycle]] and there are records and fragments from other similar productions that took place elsewhere. A [[manuscript]] of the plays, probably dating from between 1463 and 1477, is still intact and stored at the [[British Library]].<ref name=BK>{{cite book| title= York Mystery Plays: A Selection in Modern Spelling| first1= Richard| last1= Beadle| first2=Pamela M| last2= King| publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-283710-9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MBY-XnjWSA4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=beadle#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref><ref name=Davidson>{{cite book |title=Festivals and plays in late medieval Britain |first= Clifford |last= Davidson |publisher=Ashgate Publishing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HpbjszYfK8kC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22Clifford+Davidson%22&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref>
==Plays== There is no record of the first performance of the mystery plays, but they were recorded as celebrating the festival of Corpus Christi in York in 1376, by which time the use of [[pageant wagon]]s had already been established. The plays were organised, financed and performed by the York [[Guild|Craft Guilds]] ("Mystery" is a play on words, representing a religious truth or rite, and its [[Middle English]] meaning of a trade or craft). The wagons were paraded through the streets of York, stopping at 12 playing stations, designated by the city banners.
The cycle uses many different verse forms, most have rhyme, a regular rhythm with fairly short lines and frequent alliteration. The balance of critical opinion is in favour of several clerics being responsible for their authorship, one of whom is conventionally known as the "York Realist". It comprises 48 pageants that were originally presented on carts and wagons dressed for the occasion. In some accounts there are as many as 56 pageants. They told stories from the [[Old Testament|Old]] and [[New Testament]]s, from the Creation to the Last Judgement. The plays continued after the [[English Reformation|Reformation]] when in 1548, the feast of Corpus Christi was abolished in England. The plays were accommodated in to the new religious orthodoxy by cutting scenes honouring the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin]], but were suppressed in 1569.
Traditionally, an individual guild took responsibility for a particular play.<ref name=BK/><ref name=LTS/> #Barkers ([[Tanner (occupation)|Tanners]]) – The [[Creation myth|creation]], and the Fall of [[Lucifer]] #[[Plasterer]]s – The [[Genesis creation narrative|creation]] – to the Fifth Day #[[Cardmaking|Cardmakers]] – Creation of [[Adam and Eve]] #[[Fulling|Fullers]] (preparers of woollen cloth) – Adam and Eve in [[Garden of Eden|Eden]] #[[Cooper (profession)|Coopers]] (makers of wooden casks) – [[Fall of Man]] #[[Armourer]]s – Expulsion from Eden #[[Glove]]rs – Sacrifice of [[Cain and Abel]] #[[Shipwright]]s – Building of the [[Noah's Ark|Ark]] #[[Fisherman|Fishers]] and [[Mariner]]s – [[Noah]] and his Wife #[[Parchment]]ers and [[Bookbinder]]s – [[Binding of Isaac|Abraham and Isaac]] #[[Hosiery|Hosiers]] – [[The Exodus|Departure of the Israelites from Egypt]];[[Plagues of Egypt|Ten Plagues]]; [[Crossing the Red Sea]] #[[Spice]]rs – [[Annunciation]] and [[Visitation (Christianity)|Visitation]] #[[Pewter]]ers and [[Foundry|Founders]] – [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]]'s trouble about [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] #[[Thatching|Tile-thatchers]] – Journey to Bethlehem, the [[Nativity of Jesus]] #[[Candlemaker|Chandlers]] (Candlemakers) – The [[Annunciation to the shepherds]], the [[Adoration of the Shepherds]] #[[Stonemasonry|Mason]]s – Coming of the [[Biblical Magi|Three Kings]] to [[Herod the Great|Herod]] #[[Goldsmith]]s – Coming of the Kings: [[Adoration of the Magi|Adoration]] #[[Groom (horses)|Marshals]] (Grooms) – [[Flight into Egypt]] #[[Belt maker|Girdlers]] and [[Nail (fastener)|Nailers]] – [[Massacre of the Innocents]] #[[Spur]]riers and [[Bit (horse)|Lorimer]]s (Spurmakers and makers of horse bits and bridles) – [[Finding in the Temple|Christ with the Doctors]] #[[Barber]]s – [[Baptism of Jesus]] #[[Blacksmith|Smiths]] – [[Temptation of Christ|Temptation of Jesus]] #[[Currier]]s (men who dress leather) – [[Transfiguration of Jesus|Transfiguration]] #[[Cap]]makers – [[Jesus and the woman taken in adultery|Woman Taken in Adultery]]; [[Raising of Lazarus]] #[[Skinner (profession)|Skinners]] – [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|Jesus' entry into Jerusalem]] #[[Cutlery|Cutlers]] – The conspiracy: [[Pontius Pilate|Pilate]], [[Annas]], [[Caiaphas]], [[Bargain of Judas]] #[[Baker]]s – [[Last Supper]] #[[Cordwainer]]s (Shoemakers) – [[Agony in the Garden|Agony]], [[Kiss of Judas|Betrayal]] and [[Arrest of Jesus|Arrest]] #[[Bowyer]]s and [[Fletching|Fletcher]]s – [[Denial of Peter]]; [[Sanhedrin trial of Jesus|Jesus before Caiaphas]] #[[Tapestry|Tapiter]]s (makers of tapestry and carpets) and Couchers – Dream of [[Pontius Pilate's wife|Pilate's wife]]; [[Pilate's court]] #[[Dyeing|Listers]] (Dyers) – [[Jesus at Herod's court|Trial before Herod]] #[[Cook (profession)|Cooks]] and Water-leaders – Second Accusation before Pilate; Remorse of [[Judas Iscariot|Judas]]; Purchase of the [[Akeldama|Field of Blood]] #[[Tile]]makers – Second Trial before Pilate #[[Sheep shearer|Shearman]] – [[Christ Carrying the Cross|Christ Led]] to [[Calvary]] #[[Dressmaker|Pinners]] and [[House painter and decorator|Painter]]s – [[Crucifixion]] #[[Butcher]]s – [[Mortification of the flesh|Mortification]] of Christ; [[Entombment of Christ|Burial]] #[[Saddle]]rs – [[Harrowing of Hell]] #[[Carpenter]]s – [[Resurrection of Christ|Resurrection]] # [[Viticulture|Winedrawers]] – Christ's Appearance to [[Mary Magdalene]] #[[Sled]]men – [[Road to Emmaus appearance|Travellers to Emmaus]] #[[Hatmaker]]s, [[Stonemasonry|Mason]]s, [[Labourer]]s – [[Purification of the Virgin|Purification of Mary]]; [[Simeon (Gospel of Luke)|Simeon]] and [[Anna (Bible)|Anna]] #[[Scrivener]]s (Scribes) – Incredulity of [[Thomas the Apostle|Thomas]] #[[Tailor]]s – [[Ascension of Jesus Christ|Ascension]] #[[Pottery|Potters]] – [[Pentecost|Descent of the Holy Spirit]] #[[Draper]]s (Dealers in cloth and dry goods) – [[Death of the Virgin|Death of Mary]] #[[Weaving|Weaver]]s – Appearance of Mary to [[Thomas the Apostle|Thomas]] #[[Hostler|Ostlers]] (Stablemen) – [[Assumption of Mary|Assumption]] and [[Coronation of the Virgin]] #[[Mercery|Mercers]] (Dealers in textiles) – [[Last Judgment|Judgement Day]]
==The York Realist== The authorship of the plays is unknown, but analysis of the style allows scholars to recognise where authorship changes. One group of plays, concerned with the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]] has been attributed to a writer called "The York Realist"<ref name=Robinson>{{cite journal |last=Robinson |first=J. W. |date=May 1963 |title=The Art of the York Realist |journal= [[Modern Philology]] |volume= LX |issue= 4 |pages=241–251 |publisher= |doi= 10.1086/389557|url= |accessdate= }}</ref> and the name has come into general use.<ref name=BK/> The eight plays concerned are *Cutlers – Conspiracy *Cordwainers (Shoemakers) – Agony and Betrayal *Bowyers and Fletchers – Peter's Denial; Jesus before Caiphas *Tapiters (Makers of tapestry and carpets) and Couchers – Dream of Pilate's Wife *Listers (Dyers) – Trial before Herod *Cooks and Water-leaders – Second Accusation before Pilate; Remorse of Judas; Purchase of the Field of Blood *Tilemakers – Second Trial before Pilate *Butchers – Mortification of Christ; Burial They are all written in vigorous [[alliterative verse]] as are other plays in the cycle. The distinctive feature, apart from the high quality of the writing, is the attention to incidental detail in the story-telling and in the subtle portrayal of the negative characters, Pilate, Herod, Annas and Caiaphas. Playwright [[Peter Gill (playwright)|Peter Gill]] expressed the view that "If it hadn’t been for the York Realist, Shakespeare would have been a second rate writer like Goethe".<ref name=Gill>[http://dspace.dial.pipex.com/town/parade/abj76/PG/works/york_realist.shtml The York Realist] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080510153804/http://dspace.dial.pipex.com/town/parade/abj76/PG/works/york_realist.shtml |date=10 May 2008 }}</ref>
==Modern revivals== After their suppression in Tudor times, the plays remained little known until [[Lucy Toulmin Smith]] obtained permission from the [[Earl of Ashburnham]] to study the manuscript of the plays in his possession and publish her transcription together with an introduction and short glossary in 1885.<ref name=LTS>{{cite book |title= York Plays: the Plays performed by the Crafts or Mysteries of York on the Day of Corpus Christi in the 14th, 15th, and 16th Centuries| first=Lucy |last=Toulmin Smith| authorlink=Lucy Toulmin Smith| year=1885| publisher=Clarendon Press| location=Oxford}}</ref>
In 1909, the York Historic Pageant included a parade of guild banners accompanying a wagon representing the Nativity through the streets.<ref name=guilds>[http://www.yorkmysteryplays.co.uk/history.htm The Guilds of York – York Mystery Plays site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810093624/http://www.yorkmysteryplays.co.uk/history.htm |date=10 August 2009 }}</ref> In December the same year a selection of six plays was performed as a fund-raising venture for [[St Olave's Church, York]].<ref name=press>{{cite journal| title=100 years ago| journal =The Press (York)| date=29 December 2009}}</ref> The play cycle was revived on a much larger scale in 1951 in the York Festival of the Arts, part of the [[Festival of Britain]] celebrations. It was performed on a fixed stage in the ruins of [[St Mary's Abbey, York|St Mary's Abbey]] in the [[York Museum Gardens|Museum Gardens]] and directed by [[E. Martin Browne]]. The music, written for the occasion by [[James Clifford Brown|James Brown]], was directed by [[Allan Wicks]].<ref>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/5002555.Former_York_Minster_organist_Allan_Wicks_has_died/ York Mystery Plays musician and York Minster organist Allan Wicks has died], York Press, 11 February 2010.</ref> The part of Jesus was played by [[Joseph O'Conor]],<ref name=independent>Alan Strachan, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/joseph-oconor-728823.html Joseph O'Conor obituary], ''The Independent'', 2 February 2001</ref> (although to preserve mystique he was not named in the programme)<ref name="NCEM Archive">{{cite web|url = http://www.yorkmysteryplays.org/|title = NCEM Archive|accessdate = 2 September 2014}}</ref> and other roles were taken by amateurs. In the interests of comprehensibility, the text was abbreviated and modernised<ref name= Purvis1>{{cite book| title=The York Cycle of Mystery Plays: A Shorter Version of the Ancient Cycle | first= J. S. |last=Purvis| publisher=[[SPCK]]| location=London|year=1951}}</ref> by Canon Purvis who went on to lead the [[Borthwick Institute for Archives|Borthwick Institute]] at the University of York,<ref name=Borthwick>[http://www.york.ac.uk/borthwick/history/borthwick-unboxed/head-of-borthwick/ Purvis as Head of Borthwick Institute]</ref> and produced a modernisation of the complete text.<ref name= Purvis2>{{cite book| title=The York Cycle of Mystery Plays: A Complete Version | first= J. S. |last=Purvis| publisher=[[SPCK]]| location=London|year=1957}}</ref>
Following the success of the 1951 production, said to be "the most widely applauded festival event in the country, with over 26,000 people witnessing the Plays",<ref name="NCEM Archive"/> selections from the cycle were staged in the same location at three-year intervals, lengthening to four-year intervals, until 1988. They have aroused academic interest and publications.<ref name=YAYAS>[http://www.yayas.org/publications.html] YAYAS</ref> Usually directed by a professional and with a professional actor playing Jesus, the rest of the cast were local amateurs. [[Ian McShane]] played Lucifer/Satan in 1963. Some amateur actors such as [[Judi Dench]] became professionals. Directors included [[E. Martin Browne]] again (1954, 1957, 1966), [[David Giles (director)|David Giles]] (1960), [[William Gaskill]] (1963), Edward Taylor (1969, 1973), [[Jane Howell]] (1976), [[Patrick Garland]] (1980), [[Toby Robertson]] (1984) and [[Steven Pimlott]] (1988). The role of Jesus was played a second time by [[Joseph O'Conor]] (1954), then by [[Brian Spink]] (1957), [[Tom Criddle]], (1960), [[Alan Dobie]] (1963), [[John Westbrook (actor)|John Westbrook]] (1966), [[John Stuart Anderson (actor)|John Stuart Anderson]] (1973), local York man [[David Bradley (English actor)|David Bradley]] (1976), [[Christopher Timothy]] (1980), [[Simon Ward]] (1984) and [[Victor Banerjee]] (1988).<ref name="NCEM Archive"/>
In 1992 the production was moved in a modern production to the [[York Theatre Royal]], with [[Robson Green]] playing Christ and a script adapted by [[Liz Lochhead]]. The 1996 production in the same place was all-amateur, with the part of Jesus played by local solicitor Rory Mulvihill, and the script shortened by Lochhead. For 2000, the interest of the [[Dean of York]], Very Rev [[Raymond Furnell]], led him to offer the use of [[York Minster]] for the most ambitious production so far.
===York Millennium Mystery Plays=== In 2000 a large-scale performance was staged in York Minster, as ''The York Millennium Mystery Plays''. Directed by [[Gregory Doran]], with a script adapted by [[Mike Poulton]], and with [[Ray Stevenson (actor)|Ray Stevenson]] in the role of Christ, the production was the most expensive and wide-reaching project in the history of the plays' modern revival.<ref name="NCEM Archive"/> The first half began in heaven with the story of the fall of Lucifer, followed by the creation of the world, the fall of Adam and Eve, Noah's Ark (with impressive and memorable representations of the animals and the flood) and the story of Abraham and Isaac. From the New Testament there came the annunciation and nativity of Jesus, the massacre of the innocents, Christ's childhood, baptism, temptation and ministry, and his entrance into Jerusalem on Palm Sunday. The second half concentrated on the capture and trial of Christ, and his crucifixion, resurrection and ascension. The production ended, as is traditional, with the Last Judgement.<ref name=p2000>''York Millennium Mystery Plays'': Programme</ref>
The production ran for a month, with a total audience of 28,000. Aside from the professional director and actor, Ray Stevenson, the cast was made up of amateurs, mainly from the York area. More than fifty children also took part. Original music was written for the production by local composer [[Richard Shephard]].<ref name="NCEM Archive"/><ref name=p2000/>
===2012 production=== For 2012 the Mystery plays returned to the Museum Gardens, their home until 1988. The script was adapted by [[Mike Kenny (writer)|Mike Kenny]] and direction was by [[Damian Cruden]] of [[York Theatre Royal]] and Paul Burbridge of [[Riding Lights Theatre Company]].<ref name=2012prod>[http://www.yorkmysteryplays-2012.com/ York Mystery Plays 2012 website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315001438/http://www.yorkmysteryplays-2012.com/ |date=15 March 2012 }}</ref> The show involved more than 1,000 local volunteers working alongside theatre professionals in all areas of the production, including 500 amateur actors organised into two casts who shared the 30-performance run. The combined role of Jesus and God the Father was played by [[Ferdinand Kingsley]],<ref name=yorkpress>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/9721988.Meet_God___and_Jesus_Christ_/ York Press 24 May 2012]</ref><ref name=bbcyork>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-18186433 BBC News North Yorkshire]</ref> and Lucifer/Satan by [[Graeme Hawley]].<ref name=yorkpress2>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/9731921.Coronation_Street_villain_to_play_Satan_in_York___s_Mystery_Plays/ York Press 29 May 2012]</ref> Reviews for the production were generally positive, with praise for the spectacle and stage design as well as the efforts of the volunteers.<ref name=thestage1>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/37006/york-mystery-plays-2012 York Mystery Plays 2012 review in The Stage]</ref><ref name=guardian1>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/the-northerner/2012/aug/09/york-mystery-plays-st-mary-s-abbey-theatre-drama?CMP=twt_gu Guardian – The Northerner – York Mystery Plays 2012 review]</ref>
=== 2016 production === In 2016 the plays were performed in York Minster from 26 May, [[Corpus Christi (feast)|the feast of Corpus Christi]], until 30 June.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Performances - York Minster Mystery Plays|url = http://www.yorkminster.org/mysteryplays2016/the-plays/performances.html|website = www.yorkminster.org|access-date = 11 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Behind the scenes - York Minster Mystery Plays|url = http://www.yorkminster.org/mysteryplays2016/behind-the-scenes/tickets-released-next-week-for-york-minster-mystery-plays.html|website = www.yorkminster.org|access-date = 11 January 2016}}</ref> The director, Phillip Breen, had previously directed for the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Phillip Breen|url = http://www.phillipbreen.co.uk/|website = www.phillipbreen.co.uk|access-date = 11 January 2016}}</ref> Writer [[Mike Poulton]] and composer [[Richard Shepard]] repeated their millennium production roles. The cast had about 150 amateur actors and the sole professional, [[Philip McGinley]], played Jesus<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/14209643.TV_star_announced_for_Mystery_Plays__lead_role/ |title=Game of Thrones and Coronation Street star Philip McGinley will play the lead role in the York Minster Mystery Plays |publisher=[[York Press]] |date=16 January 2016 |access-date=19 January 2016}}</ref> except for the last four performances, when owing to his sudden illness the role was taken by his understudy, Toby Gordon.
=== Waggon plays === An experimental production using horse-drawn brewers’ [[Wagon|dray]]s and market stalls, was performed around [[University of Leeds|Leeds University]], in 1975.
In 1994 the Leeds-based historian Jane Oakshott worked alongside the Friends of York Mystery Plays, the Centre for Medieval Studies at the [[University of York]] and the [[York Early Music Festival]] to direct the first processional performance of the plays in modern times in York. The production involved nine amateur drama groups each taking one plays, and touring it to five playing stations in central York using pageant waggons.<ref name="NCEM Archive"/><ref name=p1994>''York Mystery Plays '94'': Souvenir Programme</ref>
A production in similar format in 1998 featured eleven plays, and for the first time the modern York Guilds were involved with some of the plays, either directly or as sponsors.<ref name=p1998>''York 1998 Mystery Plays'': Programme</ref>
Following the production in York Minster in 2000, the Waggon Plays were the only regular cycle performed in the city until 2012 when the static plays were revived. The Waggon Plays also used the Museum Gardens as a performance station maintaining the link between St Mary's Abbey and the plays established in the 1950s.
For the 2002 production management transferred to a committee of the Guilds of York: the York Guild of Building, the Company of Merchant Taylors, the Company of Cordwainers, the Gild of Freemen, the Company of Butchers, the Guild of Scriveners and the Company of Merchant Adventurers. Ten plays were produced with the assistance of local drama groups.<ref name=p2002>''York Mystery Plays'': 2002 Programme</ref>
In 2006, twelve waggons performed in the streets, in conjunction with the [[York Early Music Festival]].<ref name=p2006>''York Mystery Plays'': 2006 Programme</ref>
The 2010 production featured twelve waggons, performing at four stations.<ref name=2010w>[http://www.yorkmysteryplays.co.uk/2010_plays.htm schedule for 2010 plays] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101108191058/http://www.yorkmysteryplays.co.uk/2010_plays.htm |date=8 November 2010 }}</ref> At the same time the only known surviving manuscript of the plays was displayed in [[York Art Gallery]].<ref>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/7523511.Original_manuscript_of_York_Mystery_Plays__on_show_at_York_Art_Gallery/ Original manuscript of York Mystery Plays on show at York Art Gallery at yorkpress.co.uk]</ref>
Two plays (Creation and Noah's Ark) were performed on waggons at two stations in the York 800 celebrations in 2012.
The performances on waggons were performed by the Guilds in 2014 continuing the established four-yearly cycle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yorkmysteryplays.co.uk |title=York Mystery Plays 2014 |publisher= York Festival Trust |year= |accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> 2018 will see the plays return to the streets of York, with a selection of 11 plays.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/15509924.Mystery_Plays_back_on_the_wagons_in_2018___gallery_of_photos_of_York_Mystery_Plays_past/|title=Mystery Plays back on the wagons in 2018 + gallery of photos of York Mystery Plays past|website=York Press|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref>
=== Language in modern productions === Modern performances use some degree of modernisation of the text, either by a radical policy of replacing all obsolete word and phrases by modern equivalents, or at least by using modern pronunciations. An exception is the productions of the ''Lords of Misrule'', a dramatic group<ref name=lords>[https://sites.google.com/site/lordsofmisrule/ Lords of Misrule]</ref> composed of students and recent graduates of the Department of Medieval Studies at the [[University of York]].<ref name=cms>[http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/cms/events.html Centre for Medieval Studies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226151644/http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/cms/events.html |date=26 December 2009 }}</ref> Their presentations use authentic [[Middle English]] both in the words used and in their pronunciation. They have regularly contributed to one of the waggon play productions.<ref name=p1994/><ref name=p1998/><ref name=p2002/>
== Editions ==
===The unaltered Middle English text=== *The first publication was that of [[Lucy Toulmin Smith]] in 1885.<ref name=LTS/> This was republished in 1963 and again in 2007. *A century later Richard Beadle felt the time was ripe for re-examination of the manuscript, and he published a facsimile edition.<ref name=fax>{{cite book |title=The York play: a facsimile of British Library MS Additional 35290 : together with a facsimile of the Ordo Paginarum section of the A/Y memorandum book | first1=Richard |last1=Beadle |first2=Peter |last2=Meredith |year=1983| publisher=[[University of Leeds]]}}</ref> *Beadle also published a transcription of the text with notes and glossary.<ref name=Beadle>{{cite book |title= The York Plays| first=Richard |last=Beadle| publisher=Edward Arnold| location=London| year=1982}}</ref> This included many minor amendments to Toulmin Smith's work, but no major surprises. *Beadle's 1982 text has been put on-line at the [[University of Michigan]].<ref name=mich>[http://www.hti.umich.edu/cgi/c/cme/cme-idx?type=header&idno=York Beadle's original text at Michigan]</ref> Because this has been constrained to use a modern alphabet, the obsolete letters [[Thorn (letter)|thorn]] and [[yogh]], which are correctly reproduced in the printed version, here appear as "th" and "yo" respectively. *More recently Beadle has revised and enhanced his work into two volumes, the first containing an introduction, the text and musical settings accompanying the plays<ref name=Beadle2>{{cite book |title=The York Plays (VoIume 1 The Text) |first=Richard |last=Beadle |publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2009| isbn= 0199578478}}</ref> and the second containing notes, glossary and discussion.<ref name="Beadle2"/> *Clifford Davidson of the [[University of Rochester]] has published an edition which is also on-line.<ref name =Davidsonedn>{{cite book| title=The York Corpus Christi Plays| first=Clifford| last=Davidson| publisher=Medieval Institute Publications| location= Kalamazoo, Michigan| year=2011 | url= http://d.lib.rochester.edu/teams/publication/davidson-the-york-corpus-christi-plays}}</ref>
===Edition in modern spelling=== *The version of Beadle and King<ref name=BK/> contains a transcription of 22 of the plays into modern spelling. This is not unambiguously a benign process; where the modernisation involves the loss of a syllable it has just been dropped, which in general damages the scansion, for example is the Middle English word "withouten", which in this edition appears as "without". The Middle English ending "-and" for the present participle has been changed to the modern equivalent "-ing", but retained where the "-and" was required for a rhyme.
===Modernised editions=== *The first complete full modernisation was that of John Stanley Purvis, [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] of York, in 1951.<ref name=Purvis1/><ref name=Purvis2/> *A more recent complete modernisation is that of Chester N. Scoville and Kimberley M. Yates, in [[Toronto]], in 2003.<ref name=SY>[http://groups.chass.utoronto.ca/plspls/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/york.html Text of the York Cycle – modern English – Scoville & Yates]</ref>
== Adaptations and related plays == * ''[[The Mysteries (play)|The Mysteries]]'' is a 1977 play by Leeds poet [[Tony Harrison]] based on the York and [[Wakefield Cycle|Wakefield Mystery Cycles]]. * ''[[The York Realist]]'', by [[Peter Gill (playwright)|Peter Gill]], is set around a 1960s performance of the Plays.<ref name=Gill/> * [[Anthony Minghella]]'s ''Two Planks and a Passion'' is set around a ''c.'' 1397 performance of the plays for [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]. A radio production (starring [[Bill Nighy]], [[Julia McKenzie]], [[Julian Fellowes]] and [[Tim McInnerny]]) directed by the author was re-broadcast in 2008.<ref name=Ming>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/04_april/25/minghella.shtml Minghella]</ref> A production in July 2011 in [[York Theatre Royal]] used three professional lead actors and a large community cast.<ref name=3p1>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/9112314.Two_Planks_And_A_Passion__York_Theatre_Royal__July_1_to_16/ York Press 29 June 2011]</ref><ref name=3p2>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/theatre/9127393.Review__Two_Planks_And_A_Passion__York_Theatre_Royal_In_The_Round__until_July_16/ York Press 7 July 2011]</ref><ref name=3p3>[http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/2planks-rev British Theatre Guide]</ref> * In 2014, [[The Flea Theater]] produced ''[http://www.theflea.org/show_detail.php?page_type=0&show_id=146 The Mysteries],'' directed by Ed Sylvanus Iskandar, a six-hour show featuring modern adaptations of all 48 original York Mystery plays by 48 modern playwrights, including [[José Rivera (playwright)|José Rivera]], [[Qui Nguyen]], [[Amy Freed]], Nick Jones, Kimber Lee, Mallery Avidon and many more.
